Code
import java.util.Scanner;

public class FactorialCalculator {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        Scanner scanner = new Scanner(System.in);

        System.out.print("Enter a number to find its factorial: ");
        int number = scanner.nextInt();

        long factorial = 1;
        for (int i = 1; i <= number; i++) {
            factorial *= i;
        }

        System.out.println("The factorial of " + number + " is: " + factorial);

        scanner.close();
    }
}
Equation(latex,ascii)
f(x) = f(a) + f'(a)(x - a) + \frac{f''(a)}{2!}(x - a)^2 + \frac{f^{(3)}(a)}{3!}(x - a)^3 + \cdots

f(x) = f(a) + f'(a)(x - a) + \frac{f''(a)}{2!}(x - a)^2 + \frac{f^{(3)}(a)}{3!}(x - a)^3 + \cdots
markdown
Here is the LaTeX syntax for representing the **Taylor series** expansion of a function \( f(x) \) around \( x = a \):

```latex
f(x) = f(a) + f'(a)(x - a) + \frac{f''(a)}{2!}(x - a)^2 + \frac{f^{(3)}(a)}{3!}(x - a)^3 + \cdots
```

To make it look elegant in your LaTeX document, you can use the equation environment:

```latex
\[
f(x) = f(a) + f'(a)(x - a) + \frac{f''(a)}{2!}(x - a)^2 + \frac{f^{(3)}(a)}{3!}(x - a)^3 + \cdots
\]
```

### Key Points:
- \( f'(a) \): First derivative of \( f \) at \( x = a \).
- \( f''(a) \): Second derivative of \( f \) at \( x = a \), divided by \( 2! \) (factorial of 2).
- \( f^{(n)}(a) \): \( n \)-th derivative of \( f \) at \( x = a \), divided by \( n! \).
- \( \cdots \): Indicates the series continues indefinitely.

This will render a beautifully formatted Taylor series in your document!
